Message.Msg: at a 13 to 14 p/e that's $1.39 to 1.40 in share price.........seems like we exceeded that today alone

I missed the boat on AMZN. I sure wouldn't buy at the current price. Moody's recently announced that they were going to start to downgrade municipal bonds from states and municipalities that are not funding their retirement liabilities on a pay as you go basis. It will be interesting to see what happens if those cities and counties start to show a much bigger % of local taxes going for retirement -- some could be 15% or higher. If that happens there will be a lot of pressure to collect local taxes from AMZN and other internet retailers. Walmart and other brick & mortar retailers are lobbying hard for it. That's a big threat to AMZN's growth rate.

Message.Title: (GLBH) looks prime for a huge breakout
Message.Msg: (GLBH) looks perfect at these levels. Bottomed out and ready for a massive run

Message.Title: AMZN Cuts Some Cloud Service pricing by 80%
Message.Msg: Rackspace was down 6%. Ginni said at the recent Beirnstein conference that the way IBM entered cloud was to first work on private clouds for customers and then develop capacities for hybrid clouds with private and public elements. She pointed out that the majority of IBM's clients would want a private cloud for security. Apparently future exchanges will allow for the purchase of public cloud services on a spot basis. So the critics who said IBM was behind the curve are going to realize that public cloud services will be a commodity with thin margins. Some high flying cloud providers like Rackspace maybe Salesforce are going to see increasing margin pressure.

No one should really trust that Goldman has their best interests at heart. They are very well known for talking down a stock while loading up on it. I have no position in IBM but would be more prone to buy here then sell. Just seems like selling based on what GS says is way overdone.

trust only exists when it's earned .... GS certainly has not done that .... sounds to me like they are trying to jawbone the price down for another go 'round .... large caps have dominated the market recovery , but that dynamic is likely getting long in the tooth ... sooooooo , given that most analysts , including GS , had pegged IBM to 230+ , that would not have been much of a move from 210-215 .. drive the price down to 190 and the subsequent price recovery would give them a nice piece of quid while they are preparing to leave for a long time and get into the movement ... i take today's action to signal a short term bottom is in ... later .. g
longer term , i expect IBM to reach 20 p/e , tho' that may be 3 years out ...
